Just as NFTs have proven to be a millionaire opportunity, they are also an opportunity to carry out millionaire scams.

Unfortunately, NFT scams have multiplied and are very frequent.

Fraudsters are becoming more acute and use more complex techniques when carrying out their criminal activities.

Next, I will analyze what are the most frequent scams in NFTs so that you can avoid them, recognize them and a possible solution so that they do not happen.

1. Direct message scam

This form of scam is one of the most common in NFTs.

As a general rule, the official project website is duplicated almost identically, making it almost indistinguishable from the original.

Scammers often send direct messages to everyone interested in the project, via Discord or Twitter.

In the messages they usually send links that redirect to these fake landing pages so that you can buy the project.

In some cases, even at a lower price, so that the victims feel even more the need to buy it immediately.

Be very careful with this scam because it is really frequent.

Solution

Disable direct messages from both Discord and Twitter.

The members of the NFT projects will never send you a direct message, they will only use the official channels.

Do not click on any link that is not official and especially look at the URL, since in the falsified ones they usually change some letters.

Even so, be very careful, there are cases where scammers hack the official Discords and Twitters of the projects.

So even the official links change them for a scam link, always verify correctly before buying.

A Discord where the different chats are disabled to talk can be synonymous with it.

2. Phishing scam

Phishing is a set of deception techniques used by hackers.

It is quite frequent, and they impersonate the identity of the NFT project, pretending that they are the official ones in order to obtain the private data of the victims.

This type of scam is closely related to the direct message scam.

There are times where they pose as customer service or help support.

They chat with you on Twitter or also through email.

Never under any circumstances reveal the 12-digit secret key of your wallet to anyone, the real support staff will never ask you for it.

If you provide it to them, they will empty your wallet in a matter of seconds, not only the cryptocurrencies, they will also remove all your NFTs.

Conversation with fake Metamask support account trying to get the secret key of my wallet.

3. Pump & Dump NFT Scam

This NFT scam is very simple, and has been going on in the crypto universe since practically the beginning.

NFT scammers are in charge of increasing the price of NFT (Pump).

They are helped by a buying group that artificially increases demand.

In some cases, also from influencers and sells well-known smokes that speak of the “next hidden gem”.

When the value of the NFT is at its maximum price, it attracts hundreds or thousands of new naive users who believe they can make millions with this new investment.

At this moment, the fraudsters sell to obtain their profit and later the price of the asset begins to fall, since the demand at all times has been unreal (Dump).

Solution

Before purchasing an NFT collection, you should do a proper research of the project with your due diligence, and not put your money into something you don’t know about.

Some basic considerations are:

  • Who is the team behind? They have already created more projects or are unknown people.
  • Is there good interaction from the community? Perhaps followers are bought.
  • Is there any extra utility with this particular NFT collection? Perhaps there is no plan for the future.

Carrying out a good investigation in social networks, as well as an analysis in Opensea is almost mandatory.

Etherscan also allows you to view all Ethereum transactions for the project’s contract wallet.

4. Plagiarized project

It is very common to see plagiarism of famous projects.

One of the most frequent cases is that of Bored Ape Yacht Clubin which the scammers have replicated it ad nauseam.

Don’t be fooled, the original has a lot of value, but the fake one is worth absolutely nothing.

Anyone can download the image and upload it to Opensea to sell it at a lower price.

Under no circumstances should you buy these NFTs.

Original vs. Fake NFT

Solution

Always correctly review the NFT collection name and transaction history on Opensea.

The blue tick that appears next to the name of the collection means that it is verified within the platform.

Remember that anyone can mint an NFT and sell it on Opensea, however they are worthless.

5. Pull the rug (Rug pull scam)

The term rug pull is used in the jargon of cryptocurrencies when developers do not fulfill the promises they have kept.

As a general rule, all projects have a roadmap of the steps after the launch and disclosure of the NFT.

You might think that the worst rug pulling scam is when team members shut down all their networks and abscond to an island paradise with investors’ money.

However, this is not the most common situation.

However, by performing a lighter rug pull, they make the scam last much longer, making it much more fruitful for scammers.

Solution

Carry out a good preliminary analysis of the project as a whole and check if future plans are really viable or are just smoke.

Many projects fill roadmaps with impossible promises.

A completely anonymous and non-transparent team of developers is already a good reason to be suspicious.

conclusion

This might seem pretty strict, but question everything and assume it’s all a scam until you can verify the source.

Being always vigilant will lead you to avoid many scams in the world of NFTs.

A good precaution would be to use different crypto wallets, whether you use Metamask, Coinbase…etc

You can use one to store NFTs and the other for purchases you make.

Also, avoid having accumulated a high amount of cryptocurrencies that you are not going to use.

Still, you always have to learn from mistakes, act responsibly and know that you are investing in something very risky.
